Comment: Wow this article is a fucking mess. I was there. There were multiple hundreds of people and the event was scheduled for the performing arts center which sold out.   There was a line through the whole campus who turned out. They had to open the gym up as overflow. The senator and congressman addressed the PAC with a live stream to the gym for 1 hour and then did another hour at the gym after that.   The picture they used is from way after it was supposed to end after many had left.   Schiff answered some harsh questions around Gaza and the Democrats failures, but most of it was questions regarding due process, tariffs, and attacks on Universities.

Comment: And as the captains gazed south to the Land of Mordor, it seemed to them that, black against the pall of cloud, there rose a huge shape of shadow, impenetrable, lightning-crowned, filling all the sky. Enormous it reared above the world, and stretched out towards them a vast threatening hand, terrible but impotent: for even as it leaned over them, a great wind took it, and it was all blown away, and passed; and then a hush fell.
Author: HireEddieJordan

Comment: I see this differently.  I think the relative lack of young adult participation in the resistance is a big problem.   Most of the youngish people I know (20-30's) are either so pessimistic/depressed that they don't bother to do anything or they feel no sense of urgency (despite being very well informed) and don't bother to do anything.  Maybe they expect their helicopter moms to  come save them? In either case the result is the same.    I think we need more youngish leaders.  AOC is doing what she can, we need more like her.
Given the two groups that increase support the most in 2024 for Trump were young men, followed by young women, I'll believe it's cratering when they show up at the polls for Democrats next year.
Author: atreeismissing

Comment: Or it’s that you get type-casted as a know-nothing starry-eyed activist who hasn’t done anything to earn anything. Everybody (besides a top few) are losing something under this administration, but my generation feels like it has little to gain. The system being rigged is a common perception and there are young people out there, but they have both less to lose in an immediate financial sense and more to lose in an environmental and long-term sense. The lack of immediacy and disconnect is definitely felt. I think it’ll slowly reverse and once the immediate grocery/price shocks occur, you’ll see more normies on the street besides the college educated. We just haven’t lost our 401Ks or retirements yet.  edit: It makes sense to see those who have practiced a democratic citizenship (i.e. voting) longer to protest in these cases. Younger people are more likely to protest in social causes
Author: Inquisiting-Hambone

Comment: I get that it's human nature to ignore consequences that are too far removed from the acts that could be taken to mitigate them, but I am gobsmacked at the lack of concern for so many open and outrageous wrongs:  the assault on the very existance of transgender people, the fact that people are being illegally abducted by masked officials and sent to foreign concentration camps without a hearing, etc.    But as you suggest, people catch on at their own pace.  Maybe now that autistic people are being singled out and also threatened with forced encampment more will feel personally threatened and act.
Which of these did senator Schiff do? I must have missed the reporting.
